entry.title: Customer Insights Dashboard Enhanced with Customer Overview Card
entry.content:
We are pleased to announce the availability of the new Customer Overview Card in the Customer Insights Dashboard. This feature provides a consolidated view of key customer and partner information at a glance.

Customer Insights Dashboard Enhanced with Customer Overview Card

We are pleased to announce the availability of the new Customer Overview Card in the Customer Insights Dashboard. This feature provides a consolidated view of key customer and partner information at a glance.

The Customer Overview Card is now available in the Summary tab and provides a snapshot of the customer data selected in the main navigation area at the top of the dashboard. Positioned at the top of the Summary section, it offers quick access to the most important account details—serving as a Customer Factsheet right at your fingertips.

Select a customer to get an overview of customer details

 

What You’ll Find in the Customer Overview Card

The card combines both core customer data and information in relation to SAP.

Basic Customer Information

  • Number of customer accounts selected (from the main filter area)
  • Selected customer name(s)
  • ERP number
  • Account number
  • Corporate hierarchy details
  • Region
  • Country
  • Industry

Contractual Details

  • SAP customer since (start date)
  • Cloud customer since (start date)
  • Customer type 
  • Partner level

Why It Matters

With the Customer Overview Card, you no longer need to click through multiple sections to find basic account information. Everything is presented in one clear snapshot — helping you:

  • Save time by quickly validating the customer accounts you’re working on.
  • Understand context at a glance, thanks to corporate hierarchy and industry details.
  • See relationships with partner status, customer type, and partner level in one place.

This new feature adds clarity and transparency to your dashboard experience and makes it easier to navigate complex customer structures.

Explore the new Customer Overview Card in the Customer Insights Dashboard today and experience how it simplifies your daily work.

Related Blog: 

  • SAP Adoption PDF Report generator in Customer Insights 
  • All related blogs for Customer Insights Dashboard

entry.title: Support Entitlement Made Clearer - New Enhancements in the Customer Insights Dashboard
entry.content:
Ever felt overwhelmed by SAP abbreviations, especially when trying to understand your support entitlements? We’ve heard this feedback and introduced improvements in the Customer Insights Dashboard (CID) to make things more transparent.

Clearer View of Support Contracts and Premium Entitlements

We’ve separated the main support contract types from the premium entitlements that can be added on top. This is now presented in a simple table with three columns:

  1. Support contract code (e.g., CES, CPS, MA, PSLE)
  2. Full contract title (so you don’t have to decode acronyms)
  3. Premium entitlement and attributes

 

With this view, it’s easy to see which contracts your company holds and which premium options are attached. The table is available in the Support Contract filter at the top of CID. You can, for example, focus on Cloud Enterprise Support (CES) to view only relevant details across the dashboard.

Support Entitlement Section: What’s New

The Support Entitlement section now provides a complete overview of:

  • Your valid main support contracts, such as SAP Enterprise Support, SAP Standard Support, SAP Preferred Success, or SAP PSLE.
  • Any additional premium engagements (e.g., Active Embedded, MaxAttention, Preferred Care).
  • Related Premium Engagement Attributes (PE Attributes) like SLA, Premium SLA, or Accelerated Case Management.

Entitlements and attributes are shown at both installation and system level, with two dedicated sub-areas:

  • By Installation
  • By System

Improved Graphs and Interactivity

  • In the By System graph, the Y-axis now shows support contracts, while the X-axis displays PE attributes—making their relationship much clearer.
  • All graphs and tables are interconnected: selecting a filter in one area instantly updates the others.
  • The Support Entitlement detail table at the bottom has also been updated to include full titles for contracts and premium entitlements, so you don’t have to cross-reference acronyms.

Why This Matters

These enhancements make it far easier to see your company’s contract landscape at a glance, understand premium attributes, and filter the dashboard according to what’s most relevant for you.

entry.title: Check the Onboarding Status of Your Systems in Customer Insights Dashboard – Part 2
entry.content:
We are pleased to announce that the Onboarding section of the Customer Insights Dashboard now includes SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition data in addition to the existing SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) information.

With this enhancement, customers can track their Customer Project Implementation by SAP software product. The Onboarding section visualizes progress across key milestones such as System Setup, Access Test System, Start Data Load, Access Prod System, Start Cut-Over, and System Go-Live, based on actual system usage.

How It Works

The onboarding process for both test and production systems follows several phases ("milestones or touchpoints”) that must be completed, especially when implementing the first system of a newly purchased product.

  • SAP EarlyWatch Alert (EWA) monitors these systems starting from the moment a test system is provisioned and provides onboarding status updates based on actual system usage.
  • Following the launch of SAP IBP onboarding in February 2025, the same functionality is now available for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud with its own onboarding milestones.

Previously, this section was hidden by default and only visible through personalization settings in the dashboard. With the addition of SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Onboarding tab is now displayed by default when users access the Customer Insights Dashboard.

What You Will See

The Onboarding section presents a status overview of milestones, categorized as Reached, Not Reached, or Overdue. This makes it easy to confirm progress and identify areas where support may be needed. If milestones are not reached or are overdue, recommendations are provided in the SAP EarlyWatch Alert apps to help resolve issues.

 

Onboarding typically consists of a pair of systems (TEST and PROD). The dashboard graph shows their progress across milestones. If a system pair remains at one milestone for too long, its rating changes accordingly. Both the rating and onboarding data are collected from executed SAP EarlyWatch Alert reports.

By clicking on a milestone, users can access detailed information about the milestone, the relevant systems, and the reasons behind the current rating. A direct link to the associated SAP EarlyWatch Alert report provides further insights.

What’s Next

More products will be integrated into the Onboarding section soon — stay tuned.

Related Blogs: 

  • Check the Onboarding Status of Your Systems in Customer Insights Reporting - Part 1
  • Track Your Cloud Journey: New Onboarding Milestones in SAP EarlyWatch Alert
  • All Related Blogs for Customer Insights Dashboard

entry.title: Event enabling SAP Data Replication Framework with Advanced Event Mesh & RAP Business Events
entry.content:
Introduction

With todays enterprise landscapes becoming more and more distributed data movement and distribution is getting more and more relevant. In this blog I will go through the steps necessary to connect the SAP Data Replication Framework (DRF) with the SAP Integration Suite - Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) using RAP Business Events.

 

Disclaimer

The clean core approach for a connection between DRF and AEM, and I would recommend to apply this pattern, would be the Usage of a Standard DRF Replications provided by SAP which target an Iflow on Integration Suite (SOAP, XI or IDoc Sender Adapter) and pass the Event to AEM using the AEM Adapter. This would be a configuration only scenario and also can be monitored with SAP Application Interface Framework. 

The pattern explained in this blog is bypassing the BTP Cloud Integration and connecting to AEM directly. In addition especially for complex data structures a lot of development effort is required which makes it impractical for many use cases.

Prerequisites

This blog assumes that an AEM instance has already been setup and is connected to your S/4HANA system. Check out this blog for a detailed setup guide.

 

Setup

The setup of this pattern consists of two parts. The first one is the modelling of the event itself and the second one the required setup to trigger the event from the DRF. We'll be creating the event and everything required for it, as well as creating a custom DRF outbound implementation.

Creating the Event

Before we can send data as events to the AEM we need to develop the event itself. You can checkout this link for a details blog on how to create such events. To start lets create our BO to hold the event, starting with the initial data definition. For this blog I'll be replicating business partner data as such I'll be using the I_BusinessPartner view as root for my BO.

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Business Partner BO for DRF 2 RAP Events'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity Z_DRF_2_RAP_BP as select from I_BusinessPartner
{
    
    key BusinessPartner
}

 Next lets build the behaviour definition on top of it:

managed with unmanaged save implementation in class zbp_drf_2_rap_bp unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for Z_DRF_2_RAP_BP
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
//etag master <field_name>
{
  create;
  update;
  delete;
}

Next we need to define the event payload itself. According to the exact requirements the payload needs to be modeled accordingly in the abstract entity. Check out this blog to see how to create more complex payloads with deep structures. In this example I'll be creating just a very simple payload with the first and last name. The business partner number will automatically be included in the event as the key field of the BO.

@EndUserText.label: 'Payload for BP DRF'
define abstract entity Z_DRF_2_RAP_BP_PAYLOAD
{
    FirstName : abap.char(40);
    LastName : abap.char(40);
    
}

Next lets define the event itself on the behaviour definition. Reference the abstract entity and don't forget the deep keyword if you are using a nested payload structure.

managed with unmanaged save implementation in class zbp_drf_2_rap_bp unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for Z_DRF_2_RAP_BP
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
//etag master <field_name>
{
  create;
  update;
  delete;

  event DRF_REPLICATION parameter Z_DRF_2_RAP_BP_PAYLOAD;
}

 Next we can define the implementation class for our BO. As events can only be triggered within the implementation class of a BO we need to create and expose a wrapper method that we later can call from the DRF. For this lets define a class-method within our global class. This method should import the business partner number so that we can raise the specific event.

CLASS zbp_drf_2_rap_bp DEFINITION PUBLIC ABSTRACT FINAL FOR BEHAVIOR OF z_drf_2_rap_bp.

    PUBLIC SECTION.
        CLASS-METHODS raise_drf_event
            IMPORTING iv_bp TYPE BU_PARTNER.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS zbp_drf_2_rap_bp IMPLEMENTATION.

    METHOD raise_drf_event.
        lcl_event_handler=>on_Raise_DRF_Event( iv_bp ).
    ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

We can then raise the event within the local types. I've added a select to collect all of the required data for the business partner and pass it to the event.

CLASS lcl_event_handler DEFINITION FRIENDS zbp_drf_2_rap_bp.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    CLASS-METHODS on_Raise_DRF_Event IMPORTING iv_bp TYPE BU_PARTNER.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_event_handler IMPLEMENTATION.
   METHOD on_Raise_DRF_Event.

    DATA: tt_events TYPE TABLE FOR EVENT z_drf_2_rap_bp~drf_replication.

    SELECT SINGLE
        BusinessPartner, FirstName, LastName
        FROM I_BusinessPartner
        WHERE BusinessPartner = @( |{ iv_bp ALPHA = IN }| )
        INTO (s_bupa).

    tt_events = VALUE #(
        (
            businesspartner = s_bupa-BusinessPartner
            firstName = s_bupa-FirstName
            lastName = s_bupa-LastName
        )
    ).

    RAISE ENTITY EVENT z_drf_2_rap_bp~drf_replication FROM tt_events.

   ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

Next lets create the event binding to assign the event a topic:

 

After everything is activated you can call this method from any context to trigger the event.

 

DRF Customising

The customising of the DRF is nearly identical to the one described in Alex blog about connecting DRF with AIFAEM.

The standard object we are trying to use is 986 - Business Partner. You'll find it in DRFIMG -> Enhance Default Settings for Outbound Implementations -> Define Business Objects. The corresponding Outbound Implementation (using the standard SOAP Proxy) is 986_3. For our use case we need a custom Outbound Implementation based on this object. As such we need to copy the object to a new custom one. I named mine Z_986_3_RP

To be able to connect our RAP business event with DRF we need to adjust the outbound implementation class. Therefore we need to copy the standard implementation class of 986_3 (CL_MDG_BS_BP_REL_SERVICE_DRF) to a new custom class and reference it in our Outbound Implementation class Z_986_3_RP. I named mine Z_CL_DRF_2_RAP_BP_REPL

The class is referencing itself at multiple points. This needs to be adjusted to the new Z-Class. In addition some further mappings have to be performed which Alex described in his blog. The complete coding for the implementation of this blog can be found in the attached txt file.

The most important adjustment is however the call to our previously defined wrapper method raise_drf_event in our implementation class zbp_drf_2_rap_bp. For this I added a loop over the different entries which calls this method and passes the business partner number.

LOOP AT ls_rap_raw-business_partner_suitereplicat INTO DATA(ls_entry).

                DATA(ev_bp) = ls_entry-business_partner-internal_id.

                TRY.
                    CALL METHOD zbp_drf_2_rap_bp=>raise_drf_event
                     EXPORTING
                      iv_bp = ev_bp.

                CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_root).
                 MESSAGE lx_root->get_text( ) TYPE 'E'.
                ENDTRY.
            ENDLOOP.

Depending on the required payload of the event this can be further improved by removing the select from the method implementation and passing the data directly from the original structure.

This new Outbound Implementation needs to be assigned to a replication model.

 

This also needs to be activated within "Define Replication Model" level.

 

Test

To test this setup lets replicate the following business partner:

Create the event binding by opening transaction /IWXBE/OUTBOUND_CFG, selecting your broker and creating a new topic binding for your respective topic

 

Open transaction DRFOUT and select your replication model

Also set the manual filter criteria:

 

Press execute. The logs should then display a success.

The event itself can then be viewed in the Event Monitor (transaction /IWXBE/EVENT_MONITOR)

entry.title: Re: Cannot transfer pr to po in ME21N
entry.content: For third‑party procurement, always create the PR from the sales order (item category TAS). When converting to PO, ensure account assignment S and sales order reference are carried over. If the PO item loses the sales order reference, the system cannot update the SO and throws error V1 903. Please recheck the PR and SO linkage, and if consistent, review update terminations in SM13/ST22 or check for custom exits interfering with PO_POST. SM13/ST22 usually show the exact field mismatch.

entry.title: SAP Business Network for Logistics 2509 – What’s New?
entry.content:
The latest changes in SAP Business Network for Logistics bring tighter integration, richer data, and more guidance at your fingertips. The updates across Freight Collaboration and Global Track and Trace introduce new code-list values, enhanced APIs, improved in-app help, stronger connection controls, and expanded tracking capabilities. Here’s a concise look at what’s new and what it means for carriers, shippers, data contributors, and solution owners.

 

Cross SAP Business Network for Logistics

‘System Connection’ app: Maintain logical system IDs

You can now maintain the Logical system ID when creating a connection in the ‘System Connection’ app. This setting helps users avoiding duplicated tracking records and reduces the effort needed for configuring document links across Freight Collaboration and Global Track and Trace.

Enhancement to OAuth2.0 authentication

Beyond client credentials, carriers and data providers can now also use a client certificate (key pair) for OAuth 2.0 authentication of outbound connections. This strengthens security and adherence to your organization’s authentication requirements.

New parameter in Consumer API for Order Tracking (FC and GTT)

SAP Business Accelerator Hub: Consumer API for Order Tracking — In the Consumer API for Order Tracking (GTT) and Consumer API for Order Tracking (FC), a new parameter, serviceLevel, is added to the shipment object. It denotes the scope of agreed service provided by carriers or data contributors (e.g., milestone tracking, real-time tracking, ETA updates).

 

SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration

Code lists: New value in Document Reference Type Codes

The Document Reference Type Codes code list now includes ‘Return Sales Order (32)’. This enhancement expands reference types in documentation workflows, benefiting carriers and shippers.

New field in ‘Consumer API for Freight Booking’

A new field was added in the carrier’s ‘Consumer API for Freight Booking’. The ‘Customs Commodity Classification Code’ has been added at the item level to improve classification accuracy.

Dock Appointment Scheduling: In-app help for gate and yard

The ‘Manage Entities’ app now includes in-app help for selected fields on the gate and yard sections, such as 'Arrival Lead Time' and 'Assignment with Yards'. You can access the help by selecting the help icon in the top-right corner.

Dock Appointment Scheduling: Enhanced stop information

Stop information in the ‘Manage Dock Appointments’ and ‘Self-Book Dock Appointments’ apps now display arrival and departure timestamps, resolving discrepancies where loading and departure dates differed. The stops section supports appointments based on freight orders. If the ‘Use Derived Appointment Duration’ toggle is enabled for a loading point, the derived duration is calculated from the requested start and end dates for loading/unloading.

 

Dock Appointment Scheduling: sunset functionality to manually update external appointments

Manual updates to external appointment dates/times are no longer supported in the ‘Manage Dock Appointments’ and ‘Self-Book Dock Appointments’ apps.

 

SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace

API documentation now available in HTML version

The new API Documentation is now available in the HTML version on the product page. It consolidates content on public APIs and GTT backend service interfaces that were previously scattered across two guides.

‘Manage Models’ app: new field ‘IsFinal’ added

New completion-logic fields improve tracking fidelity, status calculations, and visibility across shipments, freight units, and related processes. In the standard model "gttft1," a new field ‘Is Final’ is added as a standard model field to all event types. It indicates whether an actual event is the last milestone event.

All fulfillment tracking apps: completion logic enhanced

Upon customer request, processes can be set to complete when the visibility provider flags and event ‘isFinal = true’. For example, an unloading event might set the status of the business document (shipment, freight unit, tracking unit or outbound delivery) to ‘Completed’.

 ---------------------

The above summarizes the key innovations for 2509. We hope you enjoy the new capabilities. Thanks for reading the blog post and stay tuned! 

A full overview of the 2509 release can be found under the following link.

To learn more about SAP Business Network for Logistics visit SAP - Business Network for Logistics.

For further questions and feedback related to the blog, please check the Q&A area and feel free to post your questions in the link with the tag SAP Business Network for Logistics.

entry.title: Re: How to activate the feature SD_SLS_PRNT_ALL_TXT_LANG
entry.content:
Hello!

Since the release 2508, this feature has been enabled by default on the system, which means the activation is not necessary anymore.

To ensure the behavior is the desired, make sure the following configuration activities are setup:

  • Define Text Types for SD Document Header (ID: 105684)
  • Define Text Types for SD Document Item (ID: 105685)

For maintaining the texts, follow the steps bellow:

  1. Change the system language for the same language as the needed for the text to appear, e.g.: Portuguese (PT).
  2. Go to the configuration activity where this text type was created (header or item)
  3. Maintain the description for the text on this language.
  4. Repeat those steps for each language the text should exist.

entry.title: Re: When will Crystal Reports implement SVG?
entry.content:
To let people know what SVG graphics are here's a description:

SVG stands for Scalable Vector Graphics, an XML-based vector image format for creating 2D graphics, charts, and illustrations on the web. Unlike pixel-based formats (like JPEG or PNG), SVG images are defined by mathematical formulas, allowing them to be scaled to any size without losing quality. They are text-based, making them searchable, indexable, and scriptable, and they support animation, interactivity, and styling with CSS. 

It's complicated.... CRD was created in the mid 90's, well before SVG was around, it was all based on C++ runtime and uses Microsoft's MEMSize for internal memory handling. According to wikipedia SVG was created in 1999.

To speed report creations, Viewing etc. CR converts all images into BMP format to reduce the file size when using Saved Data etc.

Since this image type is interactive the reports, for example a warehouse inventory report, would likely cause the report to be in giga-bytes, thus causing memory issues when viewing in WEB based app's and Desktop app's.

So it would be nice to use this feature but CR would have issues using it.

Possibly @IDO has a UFL that could use it.

 There is a site to request Enhancements but it requires a Support Contract to access....

So likely there never will be this feature added...

entry.title: Re: Reading table entries from DBTABLOG
entry.content:
Hi All,

Try the code below; it should work.

DATA:lv_object     TYPE  tabname,
     lv_table      TYPE  tabname,
     lv_date_from  TYPE  d,
     lv_date_to    TYPE  d,
     lt_change_log TYPE  /grcpi/gria_t_utchangelog,
     lv_obj        TYPE REF TO /grcpi/cl_gria_dbtablog.

CONSTANTS:  lv_object_type TYPE /grcpi/gria_object_type VALUE 'N'.

lv_table = 'ZTEST'.        "Table name
lv_date_from = '20250102'. "From Date
lv_date_to = '20250920' .  "To Date

CREATE OBJECT lv_obj.
IF lv_obj IS BOUND.
  TRY.
      lv_obj->execute(
        EXPORTING
          iv_object      = lv_table
          iv_object_type = lv_object_type
          iv_date_from   = lv_date_from
          iv_date_to     = lv_date_to
        IMPORTING
          et_change_log  = lt_change_log
      ).
    CATCH /grcpi/cx_gria_exception. " Generic Exception Class
  ENDTRY.
ENDIF.

 "Resetting ALV displays before showing a new ALV

 cl_salv_bs_runtime_info=>clear_all( ).

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite - SMB (Server message block) adapter - error STATUS_BAD_NETWORK_NAME
entry.content:

The TCP connection in cloud connector :

The SMB adapter configuration in the iFlow

Since this is a new adapter (version) by SAP, I could not find much content in the SAP community search.

If anyone has used this adapter in any integration scenario, please suggest a solution to fix this problem.

 

Regards,

Bharat Bajaj

entry.title: Message and Header exchange from Child to Parent flows
entry.content: On a request reply through a process direct adapter to a producer iFlow, I've have been trying to pass a header value from a producer iFlow (Child flow or Called flow) to consumer iFlow (Parent flow or Calling flow). We ere not able to see the header passing. We made sure the headers were maintained in both the iFlow's allowed headers of runtime configuration. None of the headers came to the consumer iFlow from producer. Astonishingly, even the message that is set on exception subprocess of the child flow is not getting passed to parent flow on failures. Is it fair to expect this behavior, or this is not even possible in SAP CPI.

entry.title: Re: List of SAP Power Designer all versions links (url) f...
entry.content:
I'll begin by providing detailed information regarding the versions. This will help ensure we are aligned and can proceed with troubleshooting.

Product version look like this:
E.g: Latest version : PowerDesigner 16.7 SP09 PL01

- Release Software level version is : 16.7 ( Family number)

- SP (Software Package) Level version is : SP09 (Latest Package)

- PL (Patch Level) is : 01
A patch level is a collection of fixes that are added to an SP. A PL contains only bug fixes, not new features.


1*** PowerDesigner 16.7  with Windows 2016 operating system 
KBA##2347515 - What is the list of supported Windows operating systems? - SAP PD 

2*** PowerDesigner 16.7 with Windows 2022 operating system
KBA##3202469 - Can PowerDesigner be installed on Windows Server 2022 - SAP PD 

If you have successfully installed SAP PowerDesigner version 16.7.8.3 on Windows 2016, please note that all other versions within the 16.7 package family are also compatible with the Windows 2016 operating system.

I’d like to confirm that you can install PowerDesigner starting from version 16.7 SP00 on both Windows Server 2016 and Windows Server 2022 operating system versions. This compatibility ensures that all versions of PowerDesigner, beginning with version 16.7  (SP00 / SP01/SP02 /SP03/ SP04/ SP05/ SP06/ SP07/ SP08/ SP09) , are supported on these platforms.

entry.title: Re: Can we connect two non sap systems using sap cpi
entry.content:
Yes, SAP CPI can definitely be used to connect two non-SAP systems. CPI is a simple yet robust middleware that provides a wide range of adapters and capabilities to integrate with heterogeneous systems, not just SAP solutions. The reason you see most packaged scenarios focusing on SAP-to-non-SAP or SAP-to-SAP integrations is because that’s the primary business need for many customers using the SAP Integration Suite.

However, there are also many valid use cases where CPI connects two non-SAP systems — for example, integrating Salesforce with Workday, or connecting third-party logistics providers with e-commerce platforms. If you explore the Discovery section of the Integration Suite, you’ll find pre-packaged integration content (ready-to-use scenarios) for common business processes, including non-SAP integrations. You can find this in the Discover section of you integrations suites' home page.

In short: while SAP-centric integrations dominate because of customer demand, SAP CPI is fully capable of handling non-SAP to non-SAP integrations as well.

entry.title: Migrating from SAP Solution Manager ChaRM To SAP Cloud ALM, how to map Types of Changes
entry.content:
Hi Team,

We are currently using SAP Solution Manager ChaRM with change document type:

  • Normal
  • Urgent
  • Standard

We don't use approval for Standard Changes.

How do we implement the same process in SAP Cloud ALM? Can we differentiate the Features in a way that we can know which are Urgent, Standard, and Normal? From the documentation we only see Requirements and Features. But if i have an Urgent Change in SAP Solution Manager ChaRM want to replicate the same in SAP Cloud ALM, how do i differentiate the Features which are Urgent ,Normal and Standard?

Kind Regards


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Migrating from SAP Solution Manager ChaRM To SAP Clou...
entry.content:
SAP Cloud ALM offers only 1 flavour of Change Document: Features.

There are (conceptually) no Urgent, Normal, or Standard Changes in SAP Cloud ALM. However it is possible to achieve a similar workflow. 

When you create a Feature in SAP Cloud ALM, there are optional fields in the "Additional Information" section. These include:

  • Workstream
  • Tags
  • Priority
  • Release

Any one (or a combination of several) of these fields can be used to classify your Features like Solution Manager ChaRM Change Documents. These fields are also filter options in the SAP Cloud ALM Features app, so you can use them to display lists of Features that meet the conditions you establish for each type of conceptual Change Document.

For example, the "priority" field can be used to establish an internal process where: 

  • All "High" and "Very High" priority Features are treated as an "Urgent Change".
  • All "Medium" priority Features are treated as a "Normal Change".
  • All "low" priority Features can be considered as a "Standard Change". 

You could establish a work process where Developers check for all priority "High" and "Very High" Features, and work on them as Urgent Changes, etc.

Alternatively, you could create workstreams that must be assigned to Features if they are "Urgent", "Normal", or "Standard". Or you could use Releases in your projects for each type of change. Features can also be "tagged" with keywords for their type (Urgent, Normal, etc.).

In summary, because SAP Cloud ALM doesn't provide different Feature sub-types, we don't have have a prescriptive way of classifying them as per the SAP Solution Manager ChaRM concepts. Our additional fields and filtering options give flexibility to choose a way of working that matches your desired workflow. But these must be established as internal processes, and are not enforced by the Features app.

entry.title: Re: Navigating the Future: Understanding Upcoming Changes to SAP Universal ID
entry.content:
Dear Community Members,

Thank you for sharing your feedback and concerns with us.

The primary change is that SAP Universal ID will no longer function as an identity provider. This modification to the login process is a crucial component of a broader initiative aimed at streamlining user management. It also serves as a technical foundation that will eventually allow customers to integrate their own corporate identity providers seamlessly.

Other substantial features of SAP Universal ID will stay: Your SAP Universal ID continues to serve as a wallet for managing your user identities. It ensures lifelong access to your account and preserves your reputation such as learning certificates and community content.

We apologize for the temporary inconvenience caused by the need to manage multiple user identities and manually switch between them due to the recent changes. SAP is currently developing an account switcher functionality to alleviate this issue.

Once the new functionality is implemented, you will log in using your S/P-user or the associated email address. After logging in, the system will display all user identities (S/P-users) linked to your UID. You can then switch to another user identity by clicking on it and entering the associated password.

For more information about future developments in authentication for digital platforms, you can refer to this News Article and YouTube interview.

To bring up improvement requests directly, join our SAP Continuous Influence session to share detailed ideas and requirements on bring your own identity, S-user management, and SAP Universal ID, ensuring clarity and effective review by SAP (an S-user is required to submit improvement requests).

entry.title: Adding Extension Fields in SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 Integrations Using Post Exit Mode
entry.content:
This blog walks you through the Post Exit Mode integration pattern using SAP Integration Suite, demonstrating how to enrich SSC V2 payloads with custom fields using OpenAPI schemas.

Step-by-Step Guide

Create Extension Fields in Sales & Service Cloud V2 + ESM 

SAP SSC V2 supports in-app extensibility via the Extensibility Administration work center.

Steps:

  • Navigate to Settings → Extensibility Administration
  • Select the relevant Entity (e.g., Employee, Products, Sales Quote, Lead, etc.)
  • Click New (+) to create an extension field
  • Define:
    • Label
    • Data Type (String, Date, Boolean, etc.)
    • Field Attributes (Required, Searchable, Sortable)



Adopt Extension Fields in entity workspace

  • Use UI Adaptation Mode to place the field in the desired section of the UI

Enable Extension Fields in OpenAPI Schema

SSC V2 is built API-first, and all entities are exposed via REST APIs documented on api.sap.com.

To include extension fields in the API:

  • Ensure the field is published
  • Check the OpenAPI schema for the entity (e.g., /salesQuotes)
  • Extension fields appear under the extensions node in the payload

Extend Standard Integration Flow in SAP Integration Suite

SAP provides pre-packaged integration content for SSC V2 and S/4HANA. To support custom fields, use the Post Exit Mode via ProcessDirect adapter.

Steps:

  • In the standard iFlow (e.g., Replicate Product), set the parameter CustomExit = true
  • This routes the message to a custom iFlow via ProcessDirect
  • The original payload is stored in the header as sourcePayload

Enrich Payload in Custom iFlow Using Groovy Script

Use Groovy scripting to parse and enrich the payload with custom field values.

Example:

def Message productReplicationExit(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(java.io.Reader)
    def json = new JsonSlurper().parse(body)

    def xmlString = message.getHeader("sourcePayload", java.io.Reader)
    def xml = new XmlSlurper().parse(xmlString)

    json.messageRequests.eachWithIndex { request, index ->
        def previousName = xml.ProductMDMReplicateRequestMessage[index].Product.PreviousName.text()
        request.body.extensions = ["ZExternalNumber": previousName]
    }

    def modifiedJson = JsonOutput.toJson(json)
    message.setBody(modifiedJson)
    return message
}

This script:

  • Extracts PreviousName from the XML payload
  • Adds it as ZExternalNumber in the JSON payload under extensions

Mapping Custom Fields from S/4HANA or ERP

In S/4HANA:

  • Use Key User Extensibility to add custom fields to business objects (e.g., Purchase Order)
  • Enable the field in the SOAP API WSDL or IDOC
  • Ensure the field is available in the outbound payload

In Integration Suite:

  • Use Message Mapping or Groovy Script to map fields from XML (S/4HANA) to JSON (SSC V2)
  • Maintain the mapping logic in the custom iFlow

Best Practices

  • Keep standard iFlows untouched: Always use Post Exit Mode to avoid losing changes during updates.
  • Use OpenAPI schemas: Ensure your SSC V2 extension fields are reflected in the schema for accurate mapping.
  • Keep Informed to customers before implement : Ensure you align with customer for addition message charges for PostExit
  • Modularize Groovy scripts: For maintainability and reusability.
  • Test thoroughly: Use Postman or SAP API Hub to validate payloads.

entry.title: Building Custom LLM Agent in Databricks: An Example Generating AI Responses from Customer Review
entry.content:
Hi Everyone!
As we know that Large Language Models (LLMs) are changing how businesses work with data and with Agent Bricks in Databricks, we can build smart agents that understand our specific business needs and are part of our data workflows. Using Generative AI, these agents can create insights, answer questions, and suggest actions, turning raw data into useful, actionable information.

Now let's deep dive into what Agent Bricks is and see how it can be put to work.

1. What is Agent Bricks?
Agent Bricks provides a simple way to build and optimize domain-specific, high-quality AI agent systems, allowing us to package LLM-based agents as reusable building blocks for common AI applications. It leverages Databricks Mosaic AI, enabling us to quickly and easily deploy comprehensive AI agent systems tailored to our unique data.
Source:
Databricks - Agent Bricks

2. Using Agent Bricks
Let us start by creating a custom LLM agent
Step 1: Identify use case

  • Define the specific purpose of your agent
  • Example: Generate AI-driven responses based on customer reviews
  • Specify the input data (e.g., customer reviews) and expected output (e.g., responses to reviews)

Lets decide our use case of "Generating AI responses from customer reviews"

Step 2: Create a labeled dataset
For our use case, we need a table with customer name and order review. As the agent accepts only one input, we have combined customer name and order review in one column called "customer_review"

Step 3: Creating a custom LLM model 
We will click on Agents tab on the left and then select Build under custom LLM model

After that in the next screen, we will enter an agent name and provide the instruction set in "Describe your task" section

The instruction set used is provided below:

You are a customer support assistant writing a response to a customer review. You are given a text where the customer name and their review are concatenated in one column.
The format is always:
<Customer Name>|<Customer Review>

    "Your task:
    1. Split the text into two parts: "customer name" and "review"
    2. Begin the response by greeting the customer using their name (e.g., 'Dear John,').
    2. Write a warm, professional and empathetic response acknowledging the customer's concern in English.
    3. Acknowledge the customer’s frustration and **apologize sincerely**.
    4. **Reassure the customer** that their concern is being taken seriously and that the issue will be reviewed to prevent recurrence.
    5. Keep the tone friendly, concise, and polite.
    6. If no follow-up reason is provided or the review is positive, write a kind Thank-you message instead.
    7. Keep the response under 100 words.

    Your response must show **genuine concern and accountability**. Always respond in fluent English.
    In the output update only response and nothing else")

After that we select the labeled dataset option and provide table name, input column and output column as shown below, and then click on Create Agent. If we want we can also use unstructured data like PDFs for our analysis by selecting unlabeled dataset.

Step 4: Train the Agent
In the next screen, we will review the guidelines created based on the instruction set and additionally more guidelines can be added. We then review the response provided by the agent to improve quality of the agent. This allows the agent to learn patterns from examples while following our custom guidelines.

We can also go to Quality Report tab to analyze the checks we have done and how is the agent performing as per our requirement

Step 5: Optimizing the agent
We can optimize the agent to be more cost effective thus saving us costs. Click on Optimize tab and select Start Optimization.

Once optimizations is complete, we can compare the quality of new agent based on our baseline agent and if it meets our requirement, we can deploy the optimized agent.

Step 6: Using the agent
We can try using the Agent by clicking on Use button as highlighted below. We can use the Agent using SQL, create an ETL Pipeline or use the agent in AI Playground.

Let's use the SQL option for our use case. Below query is generated in a new SQL editor using the custom endpoint created for our agent as highlighted below and uses the table that it is built on for testing

3. Using Agent Bricks in SQL
Once the agent is ready, we can use it via SQL in multiple ways.
First, let's create a SQL function using the custom end point of the agent and the SQL AI function "ai_query". This function will accept customer review as an input and generate AI response for each customer review.


Now lets create a table using the custom endpoint of the agent so that we can generate AI responses for all the customer reviews and save it in a table.

4. Benefits of using Agent Bricks:

  • Consistency & Reliability - Agent Bricks ensures that responses follow the rules every time. For example, if our guideline says “always include the customer’s name in the response,” the agent enforces it.
  • Reusability Across Teams -  Once created, an Agent can be reused by different teams or workflows without rebuilding  the prompt. This reduces duplication and speeds up agent adoption across the organization.
  • Quality Control - Agent can be reviewed, fine-tuned, and evaluated systematically for controlling the desired output.
  • Cost Optimization - Agent can be optimized to reduce costs and it can also save costs by using batch processing.

5. Alternative to Agent Bricks
We can alternatively create a custom SQL AI function using an LLM like LlaMA model and AI_QUERY function to achieve the same output. For example, we can write a SQL function that takes the customer name and review text as input and returns an AI-generated response.

We can then use the created function to generate the customer response

This function works fine but it has some drawbacks:

  • No Quality Testing - The output cannot be systematically tested or reviewed for quality as we cannot provide feedback to the SQL AI function.
  • Inconsistent Results - It is harder to ensure the responses follow consistent rules across large datasets.
  • Higher Cost Risk - It can have higher cost risk as each SQL query call processes data row by row.

5. Integration with SAP BDC
Currently, Agents is still in Preview in Databricks and is not available in SAP Databricks.
We hope that it becomes GA and be made available in SAP Databricks also.

As an alternate, for now, we can regenerate customer response table generated above using SQL function instead of agent and then we can share this table back to BDC using the SAP BDC connector.
We can then use this table as a data product for our case in our dashboards or reports.
Source:
SAP - Sharing Data Products from SAP Databricks to SAP Business Data Cloud 
Databricks -  Share data between SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and Databricks


We can also watch the below video shared by Arijit Banerjee that was presented by him in this year's Databricks Tech Summit:

This video clearly explains how we can share data products from SAP BDC to SAP Databricks and then make changes in Databricks and share the new tables back to SAP BDC.

Conclusion:
Agent Bricks in Databricks allows businesses to:

  • Customize AI agents with labeled or unlabeled datasets and clear instructions
  • Review and refine outputs for reliability
  • Deploy agents directly in SQL for scalable automation
  • Reduce costs by optimizing the agent

By combining data and AI, Agent Bricks helps us to unlock a new level of automation and personalization for modern businesses.

entry.title: New in SAP Cloud ALM : Risk Management for Projects
entry.content:
Risk Management in the context of SAP Cloud ALM is a structured approach to identifying, assessing, and mitigating potential issues that could negatively impact the successful delivery, operation, or adoption of a product or project. It ensures that risks are systematically captured, categorized, and monitored, enabling informed decision-making and effective prioritization of actions throughout the solution lifecycle. 

Managing risks effectively is one of the most important factors in the success of any transformation project. Whether you are running an SAP S/4HANA implementation, a system conversion, or a cloud adoption journey, risks are inevitable.

To support customers and partners in managing these uncertainties, SAP Cloud ALM now offers Risk Management as a dedicated task type. This capability makes it easier to identify, assess, monitor, and resolve risks directly in your project environment.

 

 

What is a Risk in SAP Cloud ALM?

A risk is an event or condition that, if it occurs, can have a positive or negative effect on project objectives such as scope, schedule, cost, or quality.

In SAP Cloud ALM, a Risk task type gives you a structured way to:

  • Log and document risks
  • Assess their probability and impact
  • Define ownership and responsibility
  • Plan mitigation strategies
  • Track status until the risk is resolved

 

 

Key Terminology 

Risks are defined and categorized using standard terminology. They are assessed for impact and severity, the probability of risk occurring, prioritized accordingly, and linked to related project elements 

  • Impact: The potential consequences or effects a risk may have on project outcomes if it materializes. The terminology severity and impact is used interchangeably here. 
  • Probability: The extent of damage or disruption the risk could cause; typically, a factor of impact and likelihood. The terminology Probability and likelihood is used interchangeably here. 
  • Mitigation Strategy : Actions taken to reduce the probability and/or severity of a risk. 
  • Priority: The level of urgency assigned to addressing the risk, determined by evaluating its impact and likelihood. 

 

Risk Attributes in SAP Cloud ALM

Each risk can be described with a structured set of attributes to make it actionable and trackable:

  1. Owner  – The person responsible for overseeing the risk.
  2. Responsible  – The individual or team implementing the mitigation.
  3.  Impact (1–5)  – How bad the risk could be if it happens:

    Impact 

    Label 

    Description 

    5 

    Critical 

    Severe impact: system failure, regulatory non-compliance, or project halting issues. 

    4 

    High 

    Major disruption in functionality, timeline, or cost; needs significant effort to manage. 

    3 

    Medium 

    Noticeable impact but manageable within current resources. 

    2 

    Low 

    Minor delays or issues with limited consequences. 

    1 

    Very Low 

    Minimal or no noticeable impact on delivery or quality. 

  4. Probability (1–5)  – (How likely is the risk to occur?) 

    Value 

    Impact Score 

     

    Description 

    Rare 

    1 

    Highly unlikely; may occur in exceptional circumstances. 

    Unlikely 

    2 

    Could happen occasionally. 

    Possible 

    3 

    Might happen under certain conditions. 

    Likely 

    4 

    Will probably occurs in most circumstances. 

    Almost Certain 

    5 

    Expected to occur frequently or imminently. 

     
  5.  Mitigation Strategy : 

    Mitigation Strategy 

    Description 

    Avoid 

    Change the requirement or process to eliminate the risk entirely 

    Reduce 

    Implement measures to reduce probability or impact 

    Transfer 

    Shift risk to a third party (e.g., through contracts or insurance) 

    Accept 

    Acknowledge risk but take no immediate action (used for very low-priority risks) 

    Monitor 

    Regularly observe the risk to detect changes in probability or impact 

  6.  Risk Level – Automatically calculated (Impact × Probability).
  7. Mitigation Strategy 

    Mitigation Strategy 

    Description 

    Avoid 

    Change the requirement or process to eliminate the risk entirely 

    Reduce 

    Implement measures to reduce probability or impact 

    Transfer 

    Shift risk to a third party (e.g., through contracts or insurance) 

    Accept 

    Acknowledge risk but take no immediate action (used for very low-priority risks) 

    Monitor 

    Regularly observe the risk to detect changes in probability or impact 

  8.   Risk Category:  The Risk Category field classifies each risk based on its primary area of impact. Categorization helps stakeholders filter, analyze, and prioritize risks according to their nature and relevance. It also supports targeted mitigation strategies and enhances reporting clarity across teams. 
    1.  Compliance 
      Risks related to legal, regulatory, or policy violations. Examples include GDPR breaches, missing audit documentation, or failing to meet industry standards. 
    2.  External 
      Risks stemming from external sources beyond the organization’s control, such as vendor delays, supply chain disruptions, geopolitical events, or changes in market conditions. 
    3.  Financial 
      Risks that could affect the financial performance of the organization or project, including budget overruns, cost fluctuations, or revenue shortfalls. 
    4.  IT 
      Risks related to technology infrastructure, systems, cybersecurity, or application availability. Examples include system outages, data breaches, or software integration failures. 
    5.  Organization 
      Risks associated with internal structures, staffing, change management, or company culture. Examples: key personnel leaving, lack of training, or resistance to change. 
    6.  Project Management 
      Risks related to the planning, execution, and control of projects. These include scope creep, missed deadlines, inadequate resource planning, or unclear requirements. 

 

 

 

Risk Status Values: Definitions and Lifecycle 

  1. Open
    1.  Meaning: Risk has been identified but no action has been taken yet. 
    2. Entry Point: All risks start here after being logged. 
    3. Next Possible Statuses: In Progress, Mitigated 
  2. In Progress
    1. Meaning: Mitigation or contingency planning is underway. 
    2. Requirements: An owner has been assigned, and strategies are being implemented. 
    3. Next Possible Statuses: Mitigated, closed (if risk resolved unexpectedly) 
  3. Mitigated
    1. Meaning: Mitigation actions have been implemented successfully, and the likelihood or impact is now significantly reduced. 
    2. Requirements: Documentation of mitigation effort; monitoring continues. 
    3. Next Possible Statuses: 
      1. Closed (if risk no longer exists), 
      2. In Progress (if re-evaluation shows risk has re-emerged) 
  4. Closed
    1.  Meaning: Risk is no longer relevant (resolved, expired, or no longer a threat). 
    2. Final State: No further action required. 
    3. Previous Statuses: In Progress, Mitigated 

Additional and Optional Flow: You can loop between In Progress and Mitigated if mitigation is reworked. Risks may return to In Progress if issues resurface. 

Summary of Status Transitions 

From Status 

To Status 

Reason 

Open 

In Progress 

Owner assigned; mitigation starts 

Open 

Mitigated 

Risk already mitigated before tracking starts 

In Progress 

Mitigated 

Mitigation actions completed 

In Progress 

Closed 

Risk is no longer relevant before mitigation 

Mitigated 

Closed 

Monitoring confirms risk is eliminated 

Mitigated 

In Progress 

Risk re-evaluated as active 

 

 

What’s on the Roadmap for Risk Management?

SAP is continuously enhancing Risk Management in Cloud ALM. Upcoming features include:

  • Analytics - insights to monitor, assess, and optimize risks for proactive management.
  • Assignment of Project and Subtasks – Link risks directly to project elements. 
  • Notifications for Risks – Stay informed with alerts on status changes or due dates.
  • API Enhancement – Integrate risks with external tools and reporting solutions.
  • Upload / Download – Bulk import or export risks for easier adoption.

 

A Real Project Example - Managing Risks with SAP Cloud ALM

In early 2025, global manufacturer ABC kicked off a greenfield SAP S/4HANA implementation to modernize finance, procurement, and logistics. With a strict go-live deadline in late 2025, the project team decided to use SAP Cloud ALM not only for requirements, testing, and deployments but also for risk management.

Meet Frank, the Program Manager. With over 10 years of SAP experience, he knows that unmanaged risks can easily derail a project. Here’s how he used Cloud ALM to track and resolve a real risk.

Scene 1: Risk Identified
  • Risk: Legacy system team unavailable for 4 weeks → potential delay in data migration.
  • Severity: High
  • Probability: High
  • Status: Open

Frank logs the risk in SAP Cloud ALM. The system highlights it as high priority.

Scene 2: Planning in Progress
  • Mitigation Strategy: Split migration into 2 phases, start with available teams.
  • Contingency Plan: Adjust testing timelines if needed.
  • Status: In Progress

Frank assigns the task to Michael, the Integration Architect, and monitors it weekly

Scene 3: Risk Mitigated
  • Phase 1 migration starts successfully.
  • Impact reduced to Medium, though risk remains under watch.
  • Status: Mitigated
Scene 4: Risk Closed
  • Legacy team returns on time.
  • Full migration completed before UAT.
  • Status: Closed 

Key Takeaway from Example Scenario : Using SAP Cloud ALM for risk management, Frank and his team could identify, plan, mitigate, and close risks in a structured way, keeping their project on track and protecting the go-live timeline.

 

Conclusion

With the new Risk Management task type, SAP Cloud ALM makes it easier than ever to manage project uncertainties. From logging risks to monitoring their lifecycle and applying mitigation strategies, customers and partners now have a built-in, transparent, and collaborative way to ensure successful project delivery.

 

 

Call to Action:

Start exploring Risk Management in SAP Cloud ALM today, and bring greater confidence, control, and transparency to your projects.

entry.title: Re: Business Area in S_ALR_87012082 report
entry.content: S_ALR_87012082 runs the standard report RFKSLD00 which cannot be modified. Instead, you can copy RFKSLD00 to a custom Z-report. Enhance the selection screen to include Business Area. Modify the logic to filter or display data based on Business Area. You can also explore FAGLL03 or FBL3N with Business Area as a selection criterion, depending on your reporting needs. If you don’t want to create a custom report, consider using alternative reports or custom queries via SQ01

entry.title: Re: Assign functional area based on percentages
entry.content:
Hello Jess,

thank you for your question.

In standard SAP configuration, it is not possible to assign multiple functional areas to a single cost center with percentage splits. Each cost center can only have one functional area assigned at a time – the Functional Area field in cost center master data (KS02) accepts only a single value.

Alternative approach:
To achieve a split by functional area, you would need to create multiple cost centers (e.g., Cost Center 100A and 100B) and assign a different functional area to each. Postings or allocations can then be distributed between these cost centers according to the desired percentages.
In Universal Allocation it is not possible to allocate directly into functional areas, as they cannot be used as receivers. Allocations must be made to cost centers, and the functional area is then derived from the cost center master data. Because of this 1:1 relationship, the only way to reflect multiple functional areas is through the multiple cost centers setup.

Improvement Request:
If having functional areas as direct receivers in allocations would be valuable for your processes, you may consider submitting a request on the SAP Influence Portal.

I hope this clarifies the current system behavior and possible alternatives.

Kind regards,

Diana

Product Manager in Cloud ERP

entry.title: Re: Packing Material Stock Not Reduced After Goods Issue...
entry.content:
In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, packing materials like pallets or sacs are not automatically consumed during Goods Issue unless explicitly configured. By default, the system treats them as part of the handling unit (HU) structure but does not treat them as inventory-managed items in the outbound process

Some workaround options are

  • Configure packing materials (e.g., pallets, sacs) as consumable materials. Create a Bill of Materials (BOM) or packing instruction that includes these items. Use backflushing or manual consumption during Goods Issue to reduce stock.
  • If you're using embedded EWM, you can configure automatic consumption of packing materials via pack profiles and HU management. This requires HU-managed storage locations, Proper material master setup (e.g., packing material type) and Integration with EWM consumption logic

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud – Blog #4 in the Series
entry.content:
We’ve been talking in this about how you can build your business case for modernizing to SAP HANA Cloud. However, many organizations still need help calculating the business value of migrating their database to the cloud.

A recent IDC study [1]  confirmed the value of modernizing to SAP HANA Cloud. Using a detailed business value assessmt methodology, IDC calculated that each SAP HANA Cloud database delivered US$820,000 in average annual benefits, with a 10.3-month payback on investment. Numbers like that are sure to turn heads.

This blog reviews the three beneficial features that can help you make the case for SAP HANA Cloud: native AI capabilities, built-in data integration, and automation that streamlines the duties of database developers and administrators.

Native AI capabilities

To gain value from huge volumes of business data, you need advanced AI capabilities that simplify the development and deployment of intelligent applications. 

SAP HANA Cloud is part of SAP Business Technology Platform, which offers powerful AI tools, frameworks, and services. These capabilities streamline the development and deployment of intelligent applications using machine learning and generative AI features. Extensive tools and resources, including prebuilt AI models, help you take advantage of business-ready AI.  

Multi-model engines process vast amounts of data and generate intelligent, in-context outputs. SAP HANA Cloud provides native storage, processing, and querying capabilities for AI data. A built-in vector engine handles embeddings as core data, so you can conduct similarity searches and rankings without creating separate vector databases. The database also supports retrieval-augmented generation, which helps large language models become more context-aware and integrate sensitive business context into data interactions.

SAP HANA Cloud also includes built-in, AI-enabled analytics that support predictive modeling, graph and similarity search, and time-series analysis. A predictive analysis library supports powerful features such as clustering, recommender systems, and outlier detection.  In addition, a library of 100+ business and scientific algorithms for key ML scenarios is embedded natively into the database. The IDC report suggests organizations can use these capabilities to automate insights and optimize decision-making by processing multiple data types. Study participants realized a 25% productivity increase, which translates into a value of $271,184 per enterprise.

Global cosmetics leader Natura &Co used the AI capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud with SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) to create a similarity search. The vector engine feature of SAP HANA Cloud allows users to extract information from large volumes of documents using natural language. The company also plans to use the generative AI capability to streamline business processes and support faster decision-making in its implementation of SAP S/4HANA.

Built-in data integration

Your IT landscape is complex—with data flowing to and from multiple systems, cloud platforms, and on-premises environments. Bringing this data together has always required complex ETL processes, synchronization mechanisms, and data duplication efforts. How can you simplify the integration of this business data? Realistically, every business uses data sources provided by various vendors. To bring this data together requires smooth data integration.

SAP HANA Cloud offers native connectivity with almost any data source. You can access data from SAP and third-party applications, including ERP systems, IoT devices, and external data services. The database can gain live access to sources without data replication. This integration unifies disparate data streams and creates one holistic view of your enterprise data, allowing developers to build intelligent data applications that deliver accurate, current information in real time.  

Built-in data integration capabilities include:

  • Smart data access, offering virtual data access from source systems without physical data movement
  • Simple switching between virtual data access and data replication, balancing cost and performance effectively
  • Smart data integration, enabling real-time or batch data replication with transformation capabilities
  • Hybrid connectivity, with unified connection to on-premises SAP HANA systems

Multi-model capabilities combine federated relational data with other data types, including vector embedding, spatial information, graph relationships, and JSON documents. By eliminating traditional barriers between data sources and locations, SAP HANA Cloud helps you simplify data management while creating a connected enterprise data ecosystem.

In the IDC report, respondents said the ability to gain access to real-time data from a single source helped their analytics teams accelerate data reporting. One executive working in the retail industry said, “The data is far more accessible and quicker to get with SAP HANA Cloud.”

Automation to streamline DBA duties

The workload of database developers and administrators seems to grow endlessly, as data architectures become more complex. Whether they are diagnosing and resolving issues, tuning database performance, or writing queries, these workers face a long list of highly manual tasks.

Using integrated, AI-powered tooling available with SAP HANA Cloud helps administrators work more efficiently and productively. Conversational AI features help them generate SQL statements from plain text queries, create intelligent explanations of database behaviors or issues, and automatically summarize alerts and system messages into actionable insights.

SAP HANA Cloud also automates routine database maintenance issues. The database continuously monitors system usage and offers proactive recommendations for optimization. It can identify performance bottlenecks, guide resource tuning, and suggest areas ripe for elastic scaling. Administrators can get the job done with no deep technical intervention required. 

The benefits of automation are notable. In the IDC study, companies reported a 30% efficiency boost for their database administrator (DBA) teams, resulting in an average annual business value of $336,089 per organization.

One technology organization appreciated this value. “SAP HANA Cloud provides our DBA team with more tools to help identify issues and resolve them,” said the participant. “It has increased their productivity as a result.”

Another company in the agriculture industry concurred. “The fact that SAP HANA Cloud has centralized database administration and provided flexibility to add a data lake within its data source connections has positively impacted the productivity of our DBA team,” the executive added.

Explore other SAP HANA Cloud features to build your business case

Read the final blog to learn how comprehensive security and a complete development system can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud while preparing for the future of modern, intelligent applications and processes.

 

Additional resources:

What’s the potential value of SAP HANA Cloud for your organization? Complete a short assessment. 

Learn more about SAP HANA Cloud.

Discover how moving to SAP HANA Cloud helps you create a foundation for modernization.

Explore this guide on building a compelling business case to move your database to the cloud.

 

[1]  “The Business Value of SAP HANA Cloud,” IDC, sponsored by SAP, April 2025.
